author: Staff Reporter
text:
The Madras High Court on Wednesday directed the State government to pay an interim compensation of Rs. 2 lakh to a man who was mistakenly confined in prison for four years.

He had to serve a life sentence in a crime in which he was acquitted.

The Division Bench of Justices R. Sudhakar and P.N. Prakash gave the direction while disposing of a habeas corpus petition moved by Reegan, son of the murder convict Pakkirisamy.

Relying on a Supreme Court judgement, the Bench said, “It will be in the fitness of things if the State government is directed to pay within four weeks, an interim compensation of Rs.2 lakh to Pakkirisamy for having suffered illegal detention for a period of four years, seven months and seven days, that too, without prejudice to his right to sue for damages in the Civil Court.”

Sentence was suspended

Pakkirisamy, his son Annadurai and wife Rani were tried by Additional Sessions Judge Nagapattinam in a murder case.

On October 10, 2001 the trio were convicted.

The trio preferred an appeal in 2002 before the High Court which suspended their sentences and released them on bail.

Later the High Court acquitted Pakkirisamy of the murder charge and set aside the sentence of life imprisonment.

But mistakenly, he was apprehended and remanded in custody for undergoing the unexpired portion of the sentence.

Subsequent to filing of the present petition, Pakkirisamy was released.
title: HC orders Rs. 2 lakh compensation for illegal detention
